etymologies: mid 19th century. From pin + fall, after phrases at pin

definitions: A sound made as a pin lands on a hard surface. Also figurative: something as small or inconsequential as a pin falling; a trivial incident. Compare "you could have heard a pin drop (also †fall)".
The number of pins knocked down in a tenpin bowling game; a score in tenpin bowling.

etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Delphos (Ohio) Daily Herald. From pin + fall

definitions: A fall in which a wrestler must hold an opponent's shoulders down on the mat for three seconds.
